column4: Unique customer identifier
Age of customers
column5: Assume linear relationship between age and balance (with normal noise)

column4: Occupation (categorical: "admin.","unknown","unemployed","management","housemaid","entrepreneur","student",
column5:
Assume reasonable relationship between income and jobs, based on the average salary for each occupation.
    "management": (5000, 15000),
    "entrepreneur": (3000, 16000),
    "admin.": (3000, 8000),
    "technician": (2500, 7000),
    "blue-collar": (2000, 6000),
    "self-employed": (3000, 10000),
    "housemaid": (1000, 4000),
    "services": (1800, 5500),
    "retired": (500, 3000),
    "student": (500, 2500),
    "unemployed": (0, 2000),
    "unknown": (2000, 7000)

column4: Marital Status (categorical: "married","divorced","single"; note: "divorced" means divorced or widowed)
column5: Assume anyone below 23 is single

column4: education (categorical: "unknown","secondary","primary","tertiary")
column5: Assume anyone below 18 has only completed "primary" education.

column4: has credit in default? (1:'yes', 0:'no')
column5: Assume negative balance implies default.

column4:
average yearly balance, in euros (numeric) 
note that negative balance suggests a subset of the debt that is in default
column5: Assume lognormal distribution

column4:
Total (credit) debt.
Includes credit debt that is in default (as indicated by a negative balance), and the total credit debt that has not yet defaulted.
column5:
Assume higher-income individuals tend to have higher debt
Assume individuals with negative balance are more likely to have higher debt
Assume older individuals may have lower debt due to financial stability

column4: Monthly income
column5: Assume lognormal distribution. Assume balance has a positive association with income

column4: How long customer is with the bank (in months)
Net Promoter Score (ranges from 0-10)
Number of Dependents
Estimated lifetime value of the customer
column5:
Assume individuals with high income are likely to have higher CLV. 
Assume individuals with negative balance may have lower CLV.
Assume older individuals may have slightly higher CLV due to longer tenure.

column4: Unique engagement identifier
Same as customer_id from Customers table
Same as campaign_id from Campaigns table
column5:
each campaign id corresponds to a unique campaign type, so  tiktokxinstagram have the same range of campaign ids, and telephone/landline have the same range of campaign ids.

other than  these 2 exceptions, between different channels. there should not be overlapping campaign ids

column4: Day of engagement attempt
column5: assume successful engagement is more common at the start/end of the month (salary periods etc)

column4: Month of engagement attempt
column5: assume successful engagement is more common during promotional periods and salary dates (nov-jan)
column8: All dates should fall between 2023 to 2024

column4: Duration of engagement in seconds
column5:
assume engagement duration is longer for telephone and landline, slightly less long for website n google ads, and shorter for tiktok/instagram.
(no way to track email duration)

also, randomise some NaNs values for customers who reject cookies (cannot track engagement duration)

column4: Whether customer has engaged
column5:
assume telephone/landline has extremely low engagement rates, while email, tikotk, and instagram have higher

overall, number of successful engagements is roughly 20-30% of all engagement attempts

column4: The channels utilized to promote the campaign, which may include email, social media platforms, YouTube, websites, or Google Ads.
column5:
follow marketing_campaign dataset, mapping youtube to tiktok. 

assume tiktok/instagram have a higher propotion, while landline/telephone have lower
column6:
email 
instagram
tiktok
website
telephone
landline
google ads

column4: Unique customer identifier
column5: Same as in customers table

column4: Indicator if the customer has a mobile banking app downloaded(1:Yes/0:No)
column5: Generated based on the statistic that 73% of bank account holders has the mobile app downloaded

column4: Indicator if the customer has a web banking account (1:Yes/0:No)
column5: Generated based on the statistic that 88% of bank account holders has a web account

column4: Average number of mobile app logins per week
column5: Assume the average customer pays using QR-based methods for every of their 3 meals daily, the average mobile logins would be 3 per week

column4: Average number of web logins per week
column5: Assume for the average customer web logins are on average lesser than that of mobile logins due to the ease of convinence of mobile apps

column4: Average duration (in minutes) of a mobile session
column5: Assume for the average customer mobile sessions are used mainly for short and burst checking of balances and for payments/transfers

column4: Average duration (in minutes) of a web session
column5: Assume the average customer web sessions are on average longer than that of mobile sessions due to more information on the web

column4: Timestamp of the most recent mobile login
column5: Assume recency of mobile app usage correlates with average mobile logins per week

column4: Timestamp of the most recent web login
column5: Assume recency of web account usage correlates with average web account logins per week
